												In all honesty this game should have been great, and a long time ago when it was first released this game was actually great.  Released on the Consoles in 2012, this game was a well polished and much needed intorduction to the MOBA gameplay concept to console players.The developers were fast and transparent. Fast forward almost 2 years later and the PC game is a virtual graveyard.  The game priced at 19.99 is unappealing to new gamers, and the gamers who already own it just flat out have no reason to play it. 												The MOBA/ARTS genre has exploded over the last few years. With Heroes of the Newerth, the original DotA, League of Legends and Dota 2. Now Monolith and Warner Brothers have decided to get in the fray, with Guardians of Middle-earth, a Lord of the Rings themed MOBA/ARTS game for Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3(and now PC...) If you were ever afraid that a DotA style game would be dumbed down when brought to a console, I can say that your fears are unfounded. Guardians of Middle Earth is anything but dumb, in fact it's quite deep.In Guardians, you get the typical 3-lane 6-tower map setup from a top down perspective. Exactly what you’d expect in any MOBA. A mix of upgrades for towers and buff shrines in the jungle area, between the lanes, that your team can capture. Each shrine increases a teams health regen, allowing you to stay in lanes longer, which you need to do to gain XP. While there is a single lane map I’d advise against playing it. It devolves into rage quits quite often, which ruins the experience.There are no item or gold mechanics in the individual matches, nor is there any last hitting required. These meta game elements are Call of Duty style loadouts and unlocks from experience and gold gained for completing matches. The amount of individual loadouts are gated by your account level. The items used within are gated by gold. You buy gems, potions, and relics from the in-game shop using gold. This is a way of specializing your loadouts to meet certain needs across any character. This whole area of the game is way too large to go over extensively in a review. Suffice to say, the depth and variety in loadouts is immense.The in-match skill mechanics are more to do with team work and map awareness than twitch reflexes. Movement controls with the left thumbstick. Attacks control with the right thumbstick for directional aim. Your characters face around a 360 degree axis. Your facing will also change with your movement. Holding the right stick will override the left stick’s facing controls. Allowing you to strafe and backpedal. A ring is drawn around your character showing your attack range, area of attack(usually a cone), and directional facing. It works well most of the time, but there are situations where you can’t tell if you’re hitting your target or not.Using abilities can be frustrating. You get the same ring shaped hud element for each targeted skill. These skills assign to the face buttons. I don’t know about you but I don’t have the dexterity to hit the A-button and use the right stick at the same time. You will usually end up having to aim with your movement and be careful enough not to run too far while attacking. It’s not ideal but there is a certain level of acquired skill in doing it.One nifty feature borrowed from Monday Night Combat is upgrading towers. Towers are upgraded by all players so long as they are a certain in-match level. Each of the 4 upgrade types need different minimum levels in order to apply. The creep waves are altered in the same fashion by upgrading a barracks found behind each lane’s second tower. These barracks are immune to attack until the towers in front of them are destroyed. Upgrading the barracks allows the creep wave to concentrate on different styles of pushing. Heavy siege units break enemy towers or front line fighters hold the enemy from being able to push to your base. It’s a great strategic mechanic that more games in the genre could enjoy.The Guardians are ripped straight from the pages of Tolkien's classic. They range from the bastion of good himself, Gandalf the Grey. To the epitome of evil, Sauron. And a few other notable characters like Gollum and Legolas. Each Guardian fits a different archetype and role, that create what could be a diverse meta-game. Only time and community will decide how competitive the game becomes.As for the community and player interaction: there doesn’t seem to be a lot going on in that department, at least within the game. Most players don’t seem to wear their headsets, which is a blessing and a curse at the same time. My time spent with the game has been rage and troll free, but just about every match has had someone disconnect or leave. It’s unfortunate, and I’ve yet to win a game short handed or lose a game with a numbers advantage. Luckily, queue times were short and lasted only about 2-3 minutes.There isn’t much else to say. The character design is great and borrows from the films and the sound is pretty top notch too. The graphics are as good as you’ll find on current-gen systems, if not a bit muddied. The gameplay though is the core of the experience. If you’re looking for an easy way to get yourself into the genre, Guardians of Middle-earth is one of the best chances you have.Too bad it's completely dead on arrival for PC.

												Got the game during the Warner Bros Bundle. At that time i wasn't into MOBAs so i gave it a pass.Now that i got fully acquainted with MOBAs, i decided to try it out. After all, this game was created by Monolith, the creators of No One Lives Forever, Blood and FEAR, and was the first MOBA (and the last) to hit consoles. Breakdown You have a selection of 36 heroes, in a 5v5 mode with either a solo or trilane map. One thing i would like to clear out that all the heroes are actually purchasable with ingame cash (5000 gold). The DLCs give you instant access to those heroes, along with unique skins and extra gold. To be honest, i could bear with it, since you can earn gold by just playing.When you first start the game, one thing you realize - there is no shop. Yes, last hitting doesn't matter. There are no items for you to buy. Instead they have this "belt" system. You create a belt out of 7 gems. The max level cap is 14, and every 2 levels one of your gems will activate. That's pretty much how you add stats to your heroes. Lifesteal, extra damage, crits, extra health etc ...That's the ugly part of the game. 5k for a hero i can understand. but the gems cost gold too, and their prices range from 200-5000. We are speaking about items that can make a hard carry out of you. That's unacceptable.Additionally, your belt has 4 slots for potions, which cost gold too.Finally, you have 4 slots for commands (which are all free). They are basically extra abilities, and you can choose 4 out of 16, but using 1 will put all of them on cooldown.There is no mana. Yes, abilities can pretty much be spammed, since the cooldown isn't very lengthy either.All heroes have a "free teleport scroll". Yes, they can teleport to the base. The ability has no cooldown. It cancels if you get attacked though, but still, there isn't even a cooldown.To be honest, going back to base isn't even required because each lane has healing item pick ups somewhere on the side (they look like tangos to be honest), and they heal pretty damn fast. What makes it different You can upgrade towers and barracks. When you reach lvl 6, 9 and 12, you get to choose from 4 different types of barracks that will spawn different units, and 4 different towers. The building can only have 1 upgrade, so if another upgrade is applied the first one is removed.Shrines - there are 4 points on the map, that when controlled give your team extra health regeneration and damage resistance.Defeating neutrals in the forest gives you buffs, some of which last 2 mins (kind of like runes in dota).Also, i noticed that the skin of the map changes. During my first match it looked like Osgiliath and during the second, it was Hobbiton. It practically wields no difference, but it's a nice thing to have.Other than the normal 5v5 mode, there is also a Survival mode aka Horde Mode, which is pretty good. It allows up to 5 players. Playerbase Even if you were to look down on all those problems - there is one major problem.To earn gold, you must play matches, but how would you do it if Steam db says that only 3 people are currently playing the game (one of them might have been me).You do get gold for bot matches, but it's so small (i got about 500 per match). Conclusion The game costs money, and it has heavy elements of pay 2 win.Overall, it's a poor use of the license. It's very softcore and lacks a lot of elements that make a MOBA.But hey, at least you can play it with a controller!!! No kidding, the game is pretty good with a controller. No as good as a mouse, but overall they managed it.

												The game had a rocky start and was not presented well to the public at launch. While it isn't as complex on builds as League or Dota it is a lot of fun. You can play against AI which most people won't want to do but I had a ton of fun just grabbing some friends and torching the bots. The gameplay is surprisingly good but navigating the menu system at first is a bit convoluted. There are two things that set this game apart from others in the genre for me.  Controller play - KB & M will be better in a lot of situations but the ability to play with a controller gives the game a level of fun casual enjoyment that not many of these game have. LOTR License - Learning an entirely new character or setting like in League or Dota can be fun but there is something really special about playing a games like this with characters you've known and loved all of your life. My biggest gripe with Guardians of Middle-earth is it's genre. I'm tired of playing competitive online games. Games like this, League, Dota and HOTS would be so much better if they had co-op story modes in the style of an action RPG like Diablo or Torchlight. Not to mention how important it is for games like this to maintain a strong player base or how easy it can be to lose that player base. In short if you are considering getting Guardians of Middle-earth be sure you get it to play solo against bots or get some friends and play together. Get it on sale and if you do that you might really love it.Don't go in expecting it to be the next big thing. The game is dead and will always be dead.

												The biggest problem with this MOBA is that it doesn't have a clean feel to it, smooth movement, easily explained abilities, fluid auto attacks, and super OP/Nerfed to hell characters.  I'll go through each of these, but first, I'd like to state one of the cool things about this MOBA:The system for upgrading your minions/upgrading towers is A: Easy to understand, B: actually worth using, and C: works.Now, onto the problems:The game feels like it wasn't polished or cleaned, just thrown out to the public because of deadlines.  It would be like if you took LoL from Season 1, and compared it as an equal MOBA to Season 4 LoL.  Season 1 feels gritty and awkward compared to season 4, and it's becaused it's been cleaned and polished since then.  This game needs that cleaning and polishing badly.Movement in this game is unresponsive and delayed.  You'll be trying to dodge a skill shot, or just move in random ways to fool your opponent.  Well, unfortunately, even in offline mode, it takes about half a second for your character to respond.The abilities are convoluted and stated in weird ways that don't just say "roots your enemy for 1.5 seconds" or so on.  It takes up 3-4 sentences describing it, and not really telling you exactly what it does.They had an interesting idea for the auto attacks, having melee auto attacks cleave an area in front of them, while ranged attacks will hit the first enemy in front of them.  The problem is that auto attacks are delayed, like the movement.  So by the time you auto attack, your enemy has probably killed you.Some characters in this game are just extremely powerful and others just pointless to use.  Gandalf the Grey, his E ability deals massive amounts of True damage, and it scales.  It also roots the enemy till after the damage hits.  It's insane.  Whereas Gollum/Smeagol is supposed to be an assassin who leaps in, stuns and silences, getting resets on his ultimate, but he deals 0 damage with any of his abilities.  Those are just 2 examples.If the devs were to really focus on making this game work, I think it could be something great.  However, it seems they've given up, and nothing is getting fixed.

												Guardians of Middle earth is a MOBA genre game and uses characters from JRR Tolkien LOTR and The Hobbit. Guardians of Middle earth should be played with a controller rather than a mouse and keyboard which cannot be said about any other MOBA games out there. There is no in-game item shop and the map is much smaller than in most MOBA games. Players who are  looking for a competitive MOBA will not find it here but if you are new to the genre then it is a great start. Without being able to change your items in the game because the buffs, loadout style, items are  done before the match starts it makes the game a lot easier for beginners. Guardians of Middle earth is more of a quick and fun experience that can be played in  35 minutes as there is a time limit on all games. content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Poor controls, terrible networking, and an overall flawed design prevent what would have been an amaing entry in the MOBA genre from truly succeeding.The game is designed to be used with controllers and has very poor PC optimization for mouse and keyboard. Skill activation latency when using a mouse and keyboard gives a distinct disadvantage when instant skill/item use is necessary in sudden skirmishes. Bot games are hosted server side and are plagued with the same issues. Between champion design and the LOTR namesake this game could have been a success. However, there is no late game scaling and no items to buy. The game requires a very high degree of teamwork and any player(s) who can work with one another will dominate those used to a more free style of "Champion" building that comes from games like DOTA, League, or Infinite Crisis.I obtained my copy through a Humble Bundle so I will not remark on initial cost. However, the game certainly would have been a wash for me if I HAD paid the $15 MSRP. There is also a VERY high degree of pay-to-win with in-game activated consumables that boost damage, resistance, and other useful stats. These can be purchased with currency obtained from playing games, but if you have used all your currency then you better get to the shop to acquire more, lest you lose your matches because of a disadvantage in stats.Avoid this like the plague until they fix some of the issues. Players have been complaining for months about problems and Monolith just doesn't seem to be listening. Either that or they don't know how to fix it and can't outsource a solution to save their product.If they ever fix the issues plaguing the game then I can say that in my own opinion this game could be a great success; very far down the line, mind you.

												First off, thank God this wasn't published or developed by EA.   One of my favorite companies back in the 90's, Monolith, developed the original console version.  Zombie Studios did this port which was very well done.  I first played the demo on the PS3 and now played full version on PC just recently.   It is a very solid and well-designed  but simplified MOBA - even if it was designed for the consoles first.  Unfortunately the community is not that big yet.   I think the fact that they are charging people to play it is inhibiting are larger community base.  But if you think about it,  League of Legends, HON and Demigod all started out at $30 - $40 at first but then became Free to Play (with monetization).  So they may end up making this a F2P eventually.   I think they are riding on the fact the licensed LOTR name will sell itself - and they got me. heheh.   My first impressions of it is like a mixure of Demigod and LOL. And that's why I actually enjoyed it. (You can upgrade your minions, towers, etc at the base like Demigod and you have preloadout items, relics, gems like LOL.  The only gripe I have about it is the pre-loadout screen for relics and gems is not intuitive.  You can store different layouts on several belts but after I do that I have no idea what they are because I can't name the belt and there is no "popup" to describe the items in that belt.  That is the only terrible part about the game so far...that part of the UI design. It's not up there with the hardcore MOBAs like DotA, LOL and HON but was still fun and challenging nonetheless. Since it was streamlined for the consoles, I've read that it is much easier to play with a joypad controller because it is "cone-based" aiming.  I played it with the mouse/keyboard and I didn't have to much trouble aiming.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												To their credit, when Monolith was tasked with making a Lord of the Rings MOBA they didn’t just re-skin League of Legends and call it a day. Though in hindsight, perhaps that would have been the better choice. For the uninitiated, a MOBA (generally) involves two teams of five players trying to take an opposing base. Minions flow along “lanes”, used as meatshields against enemy defensive towers. You control a powerful hero with potent abilities that level up during the course of the match. There are a lot of elements that separates GOME from its genre-brothers. Instead of having an in-match store, you purchase all your items, abilities and potions between matches using currency earned during a match. Potions are consumable buffs that need to be restocked. Abilities are utility spells, you can take four into a match. Guardian Belts hold purchasable Relics and Gems (which act like the weapon/armour items from other MOBA games). As your Guardian gains levels during a match, the belt slots unlock from left to right, unlocking the stats of the gems/relics as you go. You can upgrade the Towers that defend your lanes, and the Barracks that spew out minions. Both have four levels of upgrades that drastically improve their defensive/offensive power, giving that lane a huge advantage of a non-upgraded lane. Guardian abilities all work off cooldown counters, there are no mana or resource systems of any kind.The 36 Guardians are grouped into distinct roles: Tacticians (tanky pushers), Enchanters (high-damage nukers), Defenders (tanky supports), Strikers (glass-cannon nukers) and Warriors (middle-of-the-road). There’s cooperative play against bots, the standard five vs five online play (which puts you in a hard botmatch if it can’t find opponents), survival (five players vs waves of creatures), and a practice mode where you’re forced to play a certain character. There’s only one map, with either three or one lanes, but the map has multiple skins that change the aesthetic trimmings, chosen at random when starting. You have to pay for the game upfront, but unless you shell out for the expensive edition you only have a handful of Guardians at your disposal. The rest you buy using in-game currency, but the amount you have to play to unlock even one is ridiculous. Online, the game uses a peer-to-peer system for multiplayer instead of a server-based system, so expect a lot of lag all the time. That’s if you can even find a match: steamcharts.com which tracks players on Steam games reports GOME has at most, 20-30 people online at any time. Range indicators on abilities are unreliable, controls can be unresponsive, and you can’t even adjust the graphics settings in-game.Proving that the power of a franchise name alone isn’t enough to save a bad game, Guardians of Middle-earth is a derelict wreck. Its online community is dead, and even if you’re okay with just playing offline against bots, the core game experience is a let down.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												imo, it's legit to make a new moba if you bring something new to the genre.And Guardians of Middle-earth totally did this! Each character begin with all their abilities (except for the ultimate) and can upgrade them as they level up. And that's it. There is no other progression in the game. No gold to gain and no items to buy. (And I like this concept.) But, there is items that you can get from outside of the game. You are selecting your build before starting the game. You can't come back to the base and buy more potions, everybody have only 4 of them. There is obviously the question of peoples who pay becoming beeing more powerfull. Well, they can obviously unlock items faster but I can't tell how much faster while I couldn't find peoples to play and see how much I win for a game. I like this because you don't have to bother yourself about items to buy in-game. You just equip a set of upgrades to your character and jump in and level-up.There is also very interesting gameplay elements. Basics attacks are a cone in front of you, alloying you to hit multiple ennemies at the same time. There is a lot of secondary objectives on the map such as shrines to enhance your team and obviously a jungle. At level 6, 9 and 12, you can upgrade your tower and barracks.And it is very nice to see the character design of the LOTR characters, particullary the bad guys because we don't know much about them and they look very cool!BUT, the game is actually terrible to play. Aiming the basic attacks is awkward while they affect many ennemies but you can only focus one. Abilities are also kinda delayed and awkward to aim. It seems like you never know what ennemy you're hovering on. Also, this game is very slow on my computer. (It's a bit odd because LoL, Payday2 and Dark Souls work fine.) I can't say it's much of a bad thing because it's an old computer but, I can't change any graphic option except Resolution, Fullscreen, V-sync and one last I forgot. Anyway, there is no way to reduce the graphics quality to be able to play better.This is a shame. This game could have been Heroes of the Storm (well, the Blizard sticker is still missing) but they failled the game implementation very hard. Such a good game design gone to waste.

Posted: June 12, 2014
												This is a very similar game to Dota 2 and League of Legends in that they are moba's. The gameplay is very different though, alot of people claim the game is not smooth but I havent encountered any problems with how the game runs, but this might be because I use my xbox 360 controller instead of keyboard and mouse as this game has full controller support. Instead of the in game store that you buy items from in this game you have a belt wich automatically unlocks dfferent pieces of the belt as you rank up, the belts are made up of gems which give different bonuses such as attack speed, attack damage, and extra health, and thats barely scratching the surface and this encourages different playstyles in the game. No character in this game is exactly the same and although there are characters that are easier than others some characters require more skillful players to utilize their abilities and the characters are balanced. People complain that this game is pay to win, this is a lie as you earn in game coins at a fast rate by just playing the game and the one item you can only purchase with money does not even give you an advantage over other players. This game completely encourages teamwork and is very rewarding, but not many people are playing this game anymore so it will be hard to find teammates. The reviews from people have only spent 1 or so hours playing this game are very misleading, as any moba requires some time to get into. This is all in all a very good game and if you have a few friends that play it it is easy to form a team and do matchmaking and it is also easy to make friends in the game and this will make the game a much better experience. The only bad thing about this game is that it is not free to play and it doesnt have a large community.

												Guardians of Middle-Earth, is not a solo-playable game, instead it consists of Player versus player in match sets, as well as co-op mode versus the CPU. 												Guardians of Middle Earth is an absolutely abysmal game, ripping off other MOBAs while abusing the LOTR license. It's definitely another movie licensed cash grab, but is also an awful MOBA as well. It charges money up front but can't even compare to FREE MOBAs that it is failing to copy with any decency. It takes a big dump on its license, much like War In The North. Do not believe any positive review of this. I have to say this because this is a dreadful game. That is the truth and reality. They are lying to you, probably working for WB trying to get you to buy their crappy game. Any player that's played League or Dota2 will see right through this crap and uninstall on the first day. As a former League of Legends player myself, I can tell you that this game fails in EVERY way to compete with it, on top of charging a box just to play it. They then run a cash shop with locked content after you paid them for a box in the first place.If you want deeper details as to why this game is in every way a complete and total failure; I'll try to make a nice list for you...-Dated, muddy graphics that you can't crank up. All you get is a Resolution, Window mode, and Vsync. Nothing else. Did you like the nice amount of graphic customization in League? Well, you won't find that here. This is among the most restricted of customizations you can find. Console ports from 2009 come with more settings. Hell, Warcraft 3 from 2001 was more appealing. Not technically "better", but so much more charming and pleasant to look at even today. This game is muddy and ugly.-Crappy controls that you can't edit. That's right, like the graphics, you can't fix the controls either. They are locked in a rather awful default scheme. Unlike League, you can't hold down space to keep your hero moving. You can't use A to attack move if you like to do that. Thankfully Shift does it, but I find I use both, and many players may prefer A. The default scheme is not convenient in the least, and you can't change it. Like, why do I have to press to bring up my level up menu? Why can't that just pop up on its own like League? Why does the press for the building upgrades not even work? No, you have to press U EVERY time you want to upgrade a building. You can't change it, and the button to press for it doesn't work.-Extremely simple game mechanics. There's no AD vs AP like League, no Mana, no Energy, it's just spam spam spam when your stuff is off CD. Some League heroes are like that, but most aren't, and the game isn't built around it. Here, the game seems built for dummies, devoid of almost any strategy. Pick any hero, spam every ability, there, you're playing this game.-What customization the game does have makes no sense. You can choose between Gems and Relics(aka Runes) but you can get all of them right off the bat. So why would you even bother with the weaker ones? In League, again a game that knew WTF it was doing, lower runes were for lower levels, better runes, which cost a lot more, were for higher levels. Here you can basically get max tier runes right out of the gate, so why bother with anything less? Why does the game even have account levels??? They don't do anything!-4 Summoner abilities, renamed to "Commands", but they all share 1 CD. So what's the point of giving us 4? You're probably only ever going to use 1 or 2 out the set and just forget the rest. Btw you can't edit their default keys, which are A to F. HF with that. I should mention now that the game has no "stop" command for when you want to STOP your hero. I keep wasting my Command CD hitting S expecting my hero to STOP, but it doesn't. The game instead wastes my Command CD. So A and S are Summoner CDs, no way to change, instead of Attack Move or Stop. Wtf is wrong with this Dev team? Why is there no "STOP" hotkey???-Confusing interfaces that make it hard for me to keep up with what I own and don't own or what hero I can play or can't play.-No warring factions. This is a big FU. You've got LOTR here, a universe built around good vs evil, with many races to support it, yet you copy League(This time it's not a good thing) by having anything on either side. Wtf? So why should anyone play this over League? It should be good vs evil, yet you can see both sets of heroes on both sides at same time.-The multiplayer is dead. It takes a LONG time to find a match. I sit in queue for several minutes only to get a 2 player+3 bot vs A.I. team because the game gives up on finding a full set of 5 players. NO ONE is playing this game. In real games, like League, you push the button, 5 seconds later, you got a full match, Co Op or not.So there ya go. In summery, DO NOT get this garbage.
